prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral Imaging of W0116-0505 in [CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral Imaging of the [CII] emission line and its surrounding continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
On this "Justification Text" of our first target we detail all of the configuration parameters used for the observation, but most of the justification applies to all other targets as well. On the "Justification Text" of subsequent targets we will only explain the details that differ from those provided here.
Spatial Resolution ------------------ We expect our sources to be resolved in scales of at least a few kpc, so we have chosen to use the C34-4 configuration and obtain a spatial resolution of 0.24" in band 8 and 0.32" in band 7, corresponding to approximately 2kpc for all our targets. Hence, such resolution would allow us to obtain considerable information about spatial distribution of the gas and the dust on this Hot DOG. Although this is our preferred resolution, less detailed information from the C34-3 and C34-2 configurations will still allow us to place interesting constraints on the properties of this object, as explained in the proposal text.
Baseband Configuration ---------------------- We configure all basebands with a single spectral window, using a 1.875GHZ bandwith and a spectral average factor of 16 (velocity resolution of about 5km/s). We use this configuration to maximize the bandwidth covered and still obtain a velocity resolution useful to study the dynamics of the gas in galaxy scales.
Since one of our main science goals is to observe the [CII] emission line, we center this line in one baseband, and distribute the other three to maximize the frequency range covered. To this end we place two basebands in the lower sideband and two in the upper one, deciding the sideband of the [CII] line as to maximize the atmospheric transparency of the other basebands.
Exposure Time ------------- The exposure time is chosen to attain a sensitivity of 1mJy in 100 km/s slices, following the arguments provided in the proposal text. We select the baseband containing the [CII] emission line as the representative window.
Flux Estimates -------------- The continuum fluxes provided correspond to the continuum expected at the wavelength of the [CII] emission line for the AGN component, estimated from follow-up Herschel/SPIRE, Herschel/PACS or CSO/Sharc-II broad-band photometry. If available, we use the 500um SPIRE band flux and extrapolate the continuum flux around [CII] assuming the Rayleigh-Jeans tail of a modified black-body with beta=1.5, following the results of Wu et al.(2012). If this band is not available, we use the closest one in wavelength. Since these bands are close to the peak of the SED (see Fig. 2), the continuum flux estimates are conservative. Given that we do not know a priori if there is significant [CII] emission in these objects, we assume the line is not detectable (i.e., peak flux equal to the continuum flux estimate) although this is not relevant for the observational setup.
For W0116-0505, in particular, we use the Sharc-II 350um band flux for these estimates.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral Imaging of W0134-2922 in [CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral Imaging of the [CII] emission line and its surrounding continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The setup used is the same as for W0116-0505 but adjusted to accommodate its different redshift. We estimate the continuum flux of W0134-2922 using the PACS 170um band, which was the longest available from our follow-up photometry. Because this band is bluewards of the SED peak, we caution the reader that the continuum flux is, most likely, severely underestimated for this target.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral Imaging of W0220+0137 in [CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral Imaging of the [CII] emission line and its surrounding continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The setup used is the same as for W0116-0505 but adjusted to accommodate its different redshift. We estimate the continuum flux of W0220+0137 using the 500um SPIRE band flux.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral Imaging of W2246-0526 in [CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral Imaging of the [CII] emission line and its surrounding continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The setup used is the same as for W0116-0505 but adjusted to accommodate its different redshift. We estimate the continuum flux of W2246-0526 using the 500um Spire band flux.
This target has a higher redshift than any other, shifting the [CII] emission line into band 7, with a similar flux to the other Hot DOGs in this proposal. Since this object allow us a unique opportunity to probe the gas and dust to much fainter fluxes, we have chosen the exposure time such as to achieve a depth of 1mJy over slices of 20km/s instead.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The WISE mission has recently identified a rare population of high-redshift, hyper-luminous infrared galaxies, all with bolometric luminosities above 10^13 L_Sun, and many exceeding 10^14 L_Sun. Characterized by their extremely red mid-IR colors and very hot dust temperatures, these hot, dust obscured galaxies (Hot DOGs) likely probe a key stage in the galaxy evolution paradigm. The bulk of the IR emission in Hot DOGs is powered by AGN activity, outshining possible fainter cold emission associated to star formation. The only way to study the ISM properties of the host galaxy in these objects, as well as the effects of the AGN on it, are through kpc-scale imaging of the dust and gas at sub-mm wavelengths. We propose here to use ALMA to obtain deep, high-resolution observations of the 157.7um [CII] emission line and of the FIR continuum in a small sample of carefully selected Hot DOGs to constrain the physical properties of the their dust and gas components and gain insights into their star-formation properties.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
